text:
Is there a way to get more type information in stack traces / what heuristics are used to decide to strip them?
Debugging chains of functions whose behavior is determined by types of the arguments is much harder when  I don't know what the types are. Constructing objects of the appropriate types to debug would be easy, if I just knew what types to construct.

elements.text:

Debugging chains of functions whose behavior is determined by types of the arguments is much harder when  I don't know what the types are. Constructing objects of the appropriate types to debug would be easy, if I just knew what types to construct.

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/55226| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
I'm on Julia master FWIW (stack traces are generally much nicer in 1.6+)

elements.text: I'm on Julia master FWIW (stack traces are generally much nicer in 1.6+)

text: I normally just add a bunch of `@show`s in the functions showing up in the stack trace.

text: Hey <@UAUPJLBQX>, if you were able to find an answer here on Slack, please cross post it to Discourse via the link above. Thank you!

Starting with  `julia --inline=no` changes this:
```julia> rand(3) .+ rand(4)
ERROR: DimensionMismatch("arrays could not be broadcast to a common size; got a dimension with lengths 3 and 4")
Stacktrace:
 [1] _bcs1
   @ ./broadcast.jl:501 [inlined]
 [2] _bcs
   @ ./broadcast.jl:495 [inlined]
 [3] broadcast_shape
   @ ./broadcast.jl:489 [inlined]
 [4] combine_axes
   @ ./broadcast.jl:484 [inlined]```
into this:
```Stacktrace:
 [1] _bcs1
   @ ./broadcast.jl:501 [inlined]
 [2] _bcs
   @ ./broadcast.jl:495 [inlined]
 [3] broadcast_shape(::Tuple{Base.OneTo{Int64}}, ::Tuple{Base.OneTo{Int64}})
   @ Base.Broadcast ./broadcast.jl:489
 [4] combine_axes(A::Vector{Float64}, B::Vector{Float64})
   @ Base.Broadcast ./broadcast.jl:484```
Maybe that’s part of it?
